title: Elliott Can’t Phone in AT&T Investment
text:
Activist Elliott Management reached out and touched AT&T , T 1.49% pressuring Chief Executive Randall Stephenson. Will it have to rethink possible?

The fund run by Paul Singer disclosed a $3.2 billion stake in the company on Monday, sending its shares up by as much as 5% and even eliciting an approving tweet from President Trump. AT&T appeared in Elliott’s crosshairs after years of poor deal making and a languishing share price. Undoing Mr. Stephenson’s work isn’t simple, though.

When he took over the company in 2007, Apple ’s iPhone had only just hit the shelves. Mr. Stephenson started off with a smart decision to make wireless the cornerstone of the company’s growth, using the iPhone to gain wireless market share.

But the bump from iPhone exclusivity eventually faded and the company’s big landline business withered. Then the strategic decisions that Mr. Singer later criticized began. In 2015, well into Netflix ’s rise, AT&T spent $49 billion on DirecTV. In 2016, he launched an ambitious deal to buy Time Warner, battling regulators. Elliott’s letter criticized both deals, pointing out the company’s lack of growth in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization despite the acquisition spree. AT&T’s shares have produced a total return of 80% since Mr. Stephenson’s arrival. Cable-and-entertainment rival Comcast ’s shareholders have more than tripled their money while wireless rival Verizon ’s shareholders have gained around 150%. The Time Warner deal was nothing short of a remake for AT&T but resulted in a heavy debt load and Mr. Stephenson’s commitment to maintaining the rich dividend. Going head to head with the likes of Netflix and Walt Disney while managing the dual cash drains of paying lenders and rewarding shareholders won’t be easy, so selling off certain assets and dismantling of the deals that Mr. Stephenson has worked so hard to create might make sense. In its letter, Elliott commended Time Warner’s business but criticized AT&T’s failure to “articulate a clear strategic rationale for why AT&T needs to own Time Warner.” But marrying distribution, including DirecTV, with Time Warner’s content was the rationale for the deal. And DirecTV is housed in the AT&T’s entertainment division, which also includes its dwindling legacy voice-and-data business as well as its U-verse cable assets. The entire division could be worth what AT&T paid for DirecTV alone based on its $4.7 billion 2018 operating contribution. Elliott has the bandwidth to influence AT&T, but it risks poor reception.

description: CEO Randall Stephenson’s value-destroying ambitions left AT&T wide open for an activist, but its problems are hard to fix.
